question: How do PETs improve ad targeting with less personal data?
answer:
Pets do not directly improve ad targeting with less personal data. The information provided does not contain any details on how pets specifically impact ad targeting in relation to personal data. If you have any other questions or need further assistance, feel free to ask.

**PLEASE REVIEW**
contexts:
[' of Apps Metrics • Family daily active people (DAP) was 3.19 billion on average for December 2023, an increase of 8% year-over-year. • Family monthly active people (MAP) was 3.98 billion as of December 31, 2023, an increase of 6% year-over-year. • Facebook daily active users (DAUs) were 2.11 billion on average for December 2023, an increase of 6% year-over-year. • Facebook monthly active users (MAUs) were 3.07 billion as of December 31, 2023, an increase of 3% year-over-year. • Ad impressions delivered across our Family of Apps increased by 28% year-over-year in 2023, and the average price per ad decreased by 9% year-over-year in 2023. Beginning with our Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q to be filed for the first quarter of 2024, we will no longer report DAUs, MAUs, ARPU, and MAP in our periodic reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. We intend to begin reporting year-over-year percentage changes in ad impressions delivered and the average price per ad by geographic region, while continuing to report DAP and ARPP (calculated based on DAP), beginning with our Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q to be filed for the first quarter of 2024.

For additional information, see the section entitled "Limitations of Key Metrics and Other Data" in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. Developments in Advertising Substantially all of our revenue is currently generated from advertising on Facebook and Instagram. We rely on targeting and measurement tools that incorporate data signals from user activity on websites and services that we do not control in order to deliver relevant and effective ads to our users. Our advertising revenue has been, and we expect will continue to be, adversely affected by reduced marketer spending as a result of limitations on our ad targeting and measurement tools arising from changes to the regulatory environment and third-party mobile operating systems and browsers. In particular, legislative and regulatory developments such as the General Data Protection Regulation, including its evolving interpretation through decisions of the Court of Justice of the European Union, ePrivacy Directive, the European Digital Services Act, and U.S. state privacy laws including the California Consumer Privacy Act, as amended by the California Privacy Rights Act, have impacted our ability to use data signals in our ad products, and we expect these and other Table of Contents developments such as the Digital Markets Act will have further impact in the future.

As a result, we have implemented, and we will continue to implement, whether voluntarily or otherwise, changes to our products and user data practices, which reduce our ability to effectively target and measure ads. For example, in response to regulatory developments in Europe, we announced our plans to change the legal basis for behavioral advertising on Facebook and Instagram in the EU, European Economic Area, and Switzerland from "legitimate interests" to "consent," and began offering users in the region a "subscription for no ads" alternative. We are continuing to engage with regulators on our new consent model. In addition, mobile operating system and browser providers, such as Apple and Google, have implemented product changes and/or announced future plans to limit the ability of websites and application developers to collect and use these signals to target and measure advertising. For example, in 2021, Apple made certain changes to its products and data use policies in connection with changes to its iOS operating system that reduce our and other iOS developers' ability to target and measure advertising, which has negatively impacted, and we expect will continue to negatively impact, the size of the budgets marketers are willing to commit to us and other advertising platforms. To mitigate these developments, we are continually working to evolve our advertising systems to improve the performance of our ad products.

We are developing privacy enhancing technologies to deliver relevant ads and measurement capabilities while reducing the amount of personal information we process, including by relying more on anonymized or aggregated third-party data. In addition, we are developing tools that enable marketers to share their data into our systems, as well as ad products that generate more valuable signals within our apps. More broadly, we also continue to innovate our advertising tools to help marketers prepare campaigns and connect with consumers, including developing growing formats such as Reels ads and our business messaging ad products. Across all of these efforts, we are making significant investments in artificial intelligence (AI), including generative AI, to improve our delivery, targeting, and measurement capabilities. Further, we are focused on driving onsite conversions in our business messaging ad products by developing new features and scaling existing features. We are also engaging with others across our industry to explore the possibility of new open standards for the private and secure processing of data for advertising purposes. We believe our ongoing improvements to ad targeting and measurement are continuing to drive improved results for advertisers.

However']
ground_truth: Privacy Enhancing Technologies (PETs) improve ad targeting by reducing the amount of personal information processed, relying more on anonymized or aggregated third-party data, and developing tools that enable marketers to share their data into the systems in a way that generates more valuable signals within the apps, all while maintaining user privacy.

question: How does the MI300A's performance in FP64/FP32 stack up against the H100, given its unified memory, architectural perks, and specs like 3.4x BF16 boost, 1.6x more memory bandwidth, and 153B transistors with 5nm/6nm chiplets?
answer:
Based on the information gathered, here is a comparison of the MI300A's performance in FP64/FP32 against the H100, considering its unified memory, architectural perks, and specifications:

- The MI300A, also referred to as the MI300X, is a highly advanced processor by AMD, featuring 146 billion transistors.
- It offers up to 192GB of high-bandwidth HBM3 memory shared between the CPU and GPU, providing significant memory capacity.
- The MI300A has a memory bandwidth of 5.2 TB/s, which is 60% faster than Nvidia's H100.
- The chip incorporates Zen CPU cores and AMD's next-generation CDNA 3 GPU architecture, showcasing a powerful and efficient design.
- AMD claims that the MI300A is eight times more powerful than the previous MI250X and five times more energy-efficient.
- The MI300A is designed to handle large language models efficiently, reducing the need for multiple GPUs due to its extensive memory capacity and bandwidth.

In summary, the MI300A's performance in FP64/FP32, with its unified memory, architectural advantages, and impressive specifications, positions it as a robust and efficient processor compared to the H100. The MI300A's significant memory capacity, high memory bandwidth, and energy efficiency make it a compelling choice for demanding computing tasks.

ground_truth: The MI300A offers 1.8x the FP64 and FP32 performance compared to the H100. This improvement is attributed to its unified memory system, which avoids the need to copy memory around before it can be used, and its architectural advantages including a 3.4x boost in BF16 performance, 1.6x more memory bandwidth, and a design featuring 153 billion transistors across 5nm/6nm chiplets.

question: How does the MI300X boost general AI app performance over the MI250 with ROCm 5?
answer:
The AMD Instinct MI300X is designed to boost general AI app performance over the MI250 with ROCm 5 in several ways based on the information gathered:

- The MI300X chip is described as "the most advanced GPU for artificial intelligence" by AMD and is claimed to be able to do the work of multiple GPUs.
- The MI300X chip comes with up to 192GB of high-bandwidth HBM3 memory shared by both the CPU and GPU, which is a significant improvement over its predecessor, the MI250X.
- It has a total of 13 chiplets on the die and offers a memory bandwidth of 5.2 TB/s, which is 60% faster than Nvidia's H100.
- The MI300X chip consists of Zen CPU cores and AMD's next-generation CDNA 3 GPU architecture, making it more powerful and energy-efficient.
- AMD states that the MI300X design makes it eight times more powerful than the MI250X and five times more energy-efficient.
- The MI300X chip is designed to reduce the number of GPUs needed for running large language models, making it more efficient for AI applications.
- AMD has partnered with Microsoft to deploy the MI300X in its Azure virtual machines, indicating a strong focus on enhancing AI capabilities in cloud computing.

In summary, the AMD Instinct MI300X offers improved memory capacity, higher performance, and energy efficiency compared to its predecessor, the MI250, making it a significant advancement for boosting general AI app performance with ROCm 5.

question: How do ML techniques enhance ad targeting on socials under strict data privacy laws?
answer:
Based on the information gathered, here is how machine learning (ML) techniques can enhance ad targeting on social media platforms under strict data privacy laws:

1. **Disclosure of AI-Generated or Altered Content**: Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, has implemented a new rule requiring advertisers to disclose when potentially misleading AI-generated or altered content is used in political, electoral, or social issue ads. This ensures transparency and helps users understand if the content they are seeing is authentic or digitally altered.

2. **Realistic Content Identification**: Advertisers need to disclose if images, videos, or audio in ads have been digitally altered to show real people doing or saying things they haven't done or said. This helps in preventing the spread of misinformation and ensures that users are aware of the authenticity of the content they are exposed to.

3. **Exemption for Inconsequential Edits**: Minor edits like cropping or color correction that do not significantly impact the message of the ad are exempt from the disclosure requirement. This distinction helps in focusing on significant alterations that could potentially mislead viewers.

4. **Flagging and Logging Altered Content**: Meta will flag information about digitally altered content in ads to users and log it in their ads database. This logging helps in tracking the usage of AI-generated content in ads and ensures accountability on the part of advertisers.

In summary, by enforcing disclosure rules for AI-generated or altered content, social media platforms like Meta can leverage machine learning techniques to enhance ad targeting while complying with strict data privacy laws. This approach promotes transparency, authenticity, and accountability in digital advertising practices.

Mr. Zuckerberg’s talk was an attempt to rally staff after the most tumultuous period in his company’s 19-year history. The chief executive said he made “tough decisions” about layoffs with the goal of “building a better technology company” that shipped better products, faster — something he believed Meta wasn’t doing well as it swelled to more than 80,000 employees at the peak of the pandemic.

“I want us to use this period that’s going to be a bit more stable in order to evolve and rebuild our culture,” he said, according to two people who attended the meeting and shared remarks and a recording with The New York Times. Beginning in October 2023, additional U.S. states have filed lawsuits on these topics in various federal and state courts. We are also subject to government investigations and requests from multiple regulators concerning the use of our products, and the alleged mental and physical health and safety impacts on users, particularly younger users. Beginning with our Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q to be filed for the first quarter of 2024, we will no longer report DAUs, MAUs, ARPU, and MAP in our periodic reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. We intend to begin reporting year-over-year percentage changes in ad impressions delivered and the average price per ad by geographic region, while continuing to report DAP and ARPP (calculated based on DAP), beginning with our Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q to be filed for the first quarter of 2024.

For additional information, see the section entitled "Limitations of Key Metrics and Other Data" in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. Developments in Advertising Substantially all of our revenue is currently generated from advertising on Facebook and Instagram. We rely on targeting and measurement tools that incorporate data signals from user activity on websites and services that we do not control in order to deliver relevant and effective ads to our users. Our advertising revenue has been, and we expect will continue to be, adversely affected by reduced marketer spending as a result of limitations on our ad targeting and measurement tools arising from changes to the regulatory environment and third-party mobile operating systems and browsers. In particular, legislative and regulatory developments such as the General Data Protection Regulation, including its evolving interpretation through decisions of the Court of Justice of the European Union, ePrivacy Directive, the European Digital Services Act, and U.S. state privacy laws including the California Consumer Privacy Act, as amended by the California Privacy Rights Act, have impacted our ability to use data signals in our ad products, and we expect these and other Table of Contents developments such as the Digital Markets Act will have further impact in the future.

As a result, we have implemented, and we will continue to implement, whether voluntarily or otherwise, changes to our products and user data practices, which reduce our ability to effectively target and measure ads. For example, in response to regulatory developments in Europe, we announced our plans to change the legal basis for behavioral advertising on Facebook and Instagram in the EU, European Economic Area, and Switzerland from "legitimate interests" to "consent," and began offering users in the region a "subscription for no ads" alternative. We are continuing to engage with regulators on our new consent model. In addition, mobile operating system and browser providers, such as Apple and Google, have implemented product changes and/or announced future plans to limit the ability of websites and application developers to collect and use these signals to target and measure advertising. For example, in 2021, Apple made certain changes to its products and data use policies in connection with changes to its iOS operating system that reduce our and other iOS developers' ability to target and measure advertising, which has negatively impacted, and we expect will continue to negatively impact, the size of the budgets marketers are willing to commit to us and other advertising platforms. To mitigate these developments, we are continually working to evolve our advertising systems to improve the performance of our ad products.

We are developing privacy enhancing technologies to deliver relevant ads and measurement capabilities while reducing the amount of personal information we process, including by relying more on anonymized or aggregated third-party data. In addition, we are developing tools that enable marketers to share their data into our systems, as well as ad products that generate more valuable signals within our apps. More broadly, we also continue to innovate our advertising tools to help marketers prepare campaigns and connect with consumers, including developing growing formats such as Reels ads and our business messaging ad products. Across all of these efforts, we are making significant investments in artificial intelligence (AI), including generative AI, to improve our delivery, targeting, and measurement capabilities. Further, we are focused on driving onsite conversions in our business messaging ad products by developing new features and scaling existing features. We are also engaging with others across our industry to explore the possibility of new open standards for the private and secure processing of data for advertising purposes. We believe our ongoing improvements to ad targeting and measurement are continuing to drive improved results for advertisers.

However']

This includes relying more on anonymized or aggregated third-party data, developing tools that enable marketers to share their data into the systems, and making significant investments in artificial intelligence (AI), including generative AI, to improve delivery, targeting, and measurement capabilities. These efforts are aimed at mitigating the impact of strict data privacy laws on ad targeting.

question: How does the policy on sales return allowance affect revenue recognition for products sold with a right of return?
answer:
The policy on sales return allowance can have a significant impact on revenue recognition for products sold with a right of return. Here are some key points to consider based on the data provided:

- When products are sold with a right of return, revenue recognition may need to be deferred until the return period has lapsed or the likelihood of returns can be reasonably estimated.
- Sales return allowances are used to account for potential returns, and they represent a reduction in revenue to reflect the expected amount of returns.
- The calculation of revenue should take into account the historical return rates, current market conditions, and any specific factors that might impact the likelihood of returns.
- Recognizing revenue too early without considering potential returns could lead to overstated revenue figures and misrepresentation of the company's financial performance.
- It's essential for companies to have clear policies and procedures in place regarding sales return allowances to ensure accurate revenue recognition and financial reporting.

In conclusion, the policy on sales return allowance is crucial for companies selling products with a right of return as it directly impacts revenue recognition and financial statements. By accurately accounting for potential returns, companies can provide a more transparent view of their financial performance.
contexts:
['Our policy is to include interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as a component of income tax expense. Revenue Recognition Revenue Allowances For products sold with a right of return, we record a reduction to revenue by establishing a sales return allowance for estimated product returns at the time revenue is recognized, based primarily on historical return rates. However, if product returns for a fiscal period are anticipated to exceed historical return rates, we may determine that additional sales return allowances are required to reflect our estimated exposure for product returns. Return rights for certain stocking distributors for specific products are contractually limited based on a percentage of prior quarter shipments. For shipments to other customers, we do not allow returns, although we may approve returns for credit or refund based on applicable facts and circumstances. We account for customer programs, which involve rebates and marketing development funds, as a reduction in revenue and accrue for such programs based on the amount we expect to be claimed by customers. Certain customer programs include distributor price incentives or other channel programs for specific products and customer classes which require judgement as to whether the applicable incentives will be attained.

Estimates for customer program accruals include a combination of historical attainment and claim rates and may be adjusted based on relevant internal and external factors. License and Development Arrangements Revenue from License and Development Arrangements is recognized over the period in which the development services are performed. Each fiscal reporting period, we measure progress to completion based on actual cost incurred to date as a percentage of the estimated total cost required to complete each project. Estimated total cost for each project includes a forecast of internal engineer personnel time expected to be incurred and other third-party costs as applicable. Contracts with Multiple Performance Obligations Our contracts may contain more than one performance obligation. Judgement is required in determining whether each performance obligation within a customer contract is distinct. Except for License and Development Arrangements, NVIDIA products and services function on a standalone basis and do not require a significant amount of integration or interdependency. Therefore, multiple performance obligations contained within a customer contract are considered distinct and are not combined for revenue recognition purposes. We allocate the total transaction price to each distinct performance obligation in a multiple performance obligations arrangement on a relative standalone selling price basis.

In certain cases, we can establish standalone selling price based on directly observable prices of products or services sold separately in comparable circumstances to similar customers. If standalone selling price is not directly observable, such as when we do not sell a product or service separately, we determine standalone selling price based on market data and other observable inputs. Change in Accounting Estimate In February 2023, we assessed the useful lives of our property, plant, and equipment. Based on advances in technology and usage rate, we increased the estimated useful life of a majority of the server, storage, and network equipment from three years to a range of four to five years, and assembly and test equipment from five years to seven years. The estimated effect of this change for fiscal year 2024 was a benefit of $33 million and $102 million for cost of revenue and operating expenses, respectively, which resulted in an increase in operating income of $135 million and net income of $114 million after tax, or $0.05 per both basic and diluted share. Results of Operations A discussion regarding our financial condition and results of operations for fiscal year 2024 compared to fiscal year 2023 is presented below.

A discussion regarding our financial condition and results of operations for fiscal year 2023 compared to fiscal year 2022 can be found under Item 7 in our Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended January 29, 2023, filed with the SEC on February 24, 2023, which is available free of charge on the SEC’s website at http://www.sec.gov and at our investor relations website, http://investor.nvidia.com. The following table sets forth, for the periods indicated, certain items in our Consolidated Statements of Income expressed as a percentage of revenue.

##TABLE_START   Year Ended   Jan 28, 2024 Jan 29, 2023 Revenue 100.0 % 100.0 % Cost of revenue 27.3 43.1 Gross profit 72.7 56.9 Operating expenses   Research and development 14.2 27.2 Sales, general and administrative 4.4 9.1 Acquisition termination cost — 5.0 Total operating expenses 18.6 41.3 Operating income 54.1 15.6 Interest income 1.4 1.0 Interest expense (0.4) (1.0) Other, net 0.4 (0.1) Other income (expense), net 1.4 (0.1) Income before income tax 55.5 15.5 Income tax expense (benefit) 6.6 (0.7) Net income 48.9 % 16.2 % ##TABLE_END Reportable Segments Revenue by Reportable Segments ##TABLE_START Year Ended Jan 28, 2024 Jan 29,']
ground_truth: The policy on sales return allowance affects revenue recognition for products sold with a right of return by recording a reduction to revenue. This reduction is established by creating a sales return allowance for estimated product returns at the time revenue is recognized, based primarily on historical return rates. If product returns for a fiscal period are anticipated to exceed historical return rates, additional sales return allowances may be required to reflect the estimated exposure for product returns.

question: How do ROCm 6's tech enhancements boost MI300X's AI performance 8x over MI250, and its impact on partnerships and AI software integration?
answer:
The AMD Instinct MI300X, with its advanced technology enhancements, significantly boosts AI performance over the MI250X and has a notable impact on partnerships and AI software integration. Here is a breakdown of how these enhancements contribute to the performance increase and the broader implications:

1. **Performance Boost**:
   - The MI300X is designed with up to 192GB of high-bandwidth HBM3 memory shared between the CPU and GPU, offering a substantial increase in memory capacity.
   - It features Zen CPU cores and AMD’s next-generation CDNA 3 GPU architecture, optimizing performance for AI workloads.
   - With a memory bandwidth of 5.2 TB/s, which is 60% faster than Nvidia’s H100, the MI300X can handle larger model sizes efficiently.
   - The chip's design allows for a reduction in the number of GPUs required to run large language models, making it more powerful and energy-efficient.

2. **Partnerships and Market Impact**:
   - AMD's introduction of the MI300X poses a significant challenge to Nvidia, which currently dominates the AI chip market.
   - If embraced by developers and server manufacturers as a viable alternative to Nvidia's products, AMD could tap into a substantial market opportunity in the AI accelerator segment.
   - The growth potential in the data center AI accelerator market is substantial, with projections indicating a significant increase in market size by 2027.
   - Lower GPU prices resulting from competition between AMD and Nvidia could help reduce the overall cost of serving generative AI applications.

3. **Software Integration**:
   - The MI300X's advanced capabilities are likely to drive software developers to leverage its features for enhanced AI performance.
   - APIs and tools provided by AMD for the MI300X will enable developers to optimize their AI applications and offload tasks efficiently.
   - The chip's architecture and performance improvements will facilitate smoother integration with existing AI software frameworks and tools.

In conclusion, the AMD Instinct MI300X's tech enhancements, including increased memory capacity, optimized architecture, and improved efficiency, play a crucial role in boosting AI performance and have far-reaching implications for partnerships, market dynamics, and AI software integration.

ground_truth: ROCm 6's tech enhancements, including optimized libraries and HIP Graph, contribute to an 8x increase in GenAI performance on MI300X versus MI250. This performance boost, combined with hardware changes, facilitates deeper partnerships and AI software integration, as evidenced by the support from major cloud computing customers and the integration of AMD GPUs in the OpenAI Triton 3.0 release. The improvements in ROCm 6 and the hardware's capabilities have made AMD's platform more attractive to partners, leading to a broader adoption in various sectors and support for a significant number of models running on AMD hardware.

question: What are the benefits of choosing AMD Ryzen 9 7900 for power efficiency and performance per watt?
answer:
The AMD Ryzen 9 7900 offers several benefits in terms of power efficiency and performance per watt:

- The Ryzen 9 7900 is designed to operate close to its thermal limit, allowing it to achieve maximum performance within its thermal limitations while consuming less power compared to higher-power models like the 7900X.
- The Ryzen 9 7900 has a lower power consumption with a 65W TDP and 88W socket draw, making it more power-efficient without sacrificing performance.
- The Ryzen 9 7900 features a base clock rate of 3.7GHz and a maximum boost frequency of 5.4GHz, providing a balance between power efficiency and performance.
- The Ryzen 9 7900 shares the same hardware design as the 7900X, featuring a two-CCD chiplet design with 12 cores and 24 threads, ensuring efficient multitasking capabilities.
- The included Wraith Prism cooler with the Ryzen 9 7900 is rated for 105W TDP, providing effective cooling performance while maintaining power efficiency.
- In benchmarks, the Ryzen 9 7900 demonstrated exceptional performance per watt, showing efficiency in various tasks compared to higher-power CPUs like the 7900X and Intel Core i7-13700K.
- The Ryzen 9 7900 offers a balance between performance and power efficiency, making it a suitable choice for users looking for a capable and low-power 12-core CPU.

In conclusion, the AMD Ryzen 9 7900 stands out for its power efficiency and performance per watt, making it a compelling option for users seeking a balance between performance and energy efficiency in their desktop CPUs.

PLEASE REVIEW
contexts:
[" voltage and power draw, generated excessive heat in this task and lowered its clock speed accordingly. The 7900, running on a much lower power curve, but using the same cooler, has less heat debt to contend with and so was able to match the 7900X frequency in this benchmark.

All other benchmarks in this suite showed no surprises. The Ryzen 9 7900X, with its generous power allowance, could almost always maintain a higher clock frequency under heavy load. The 7900X was slightly ahead of the 7900 in Photoshop and the single-thread benches, and the lead often grew in multi-threaded tasks.

As we saw the Intel Core i7-13700K ahead of the Ryzen 9 7900X in the last review, it had an even bigger advantage here when the AMD chip was limited by power draw. The Core i5-13600K is now almost a dead tie with the 7900 in all aspects.

Testing the AMD Ryzen 9 7900: Discrete Graphics Benchmarks

Our gaming results are no different than we saw in the Ryzen 9 7900X review. The synthetic Time Spy bench is designed to test all CPU capabilities, not just those most commonly used in games, and showed more separation in the CPU models. Otherwise, any Ryzen 7000 chip not equipped with 3D V-Cache was practically indistinguishable from another when paired with a RTX 3080. Intel's Raptor Lake CPUs had small wins in a few titles. Games have certainly become more multi-threaded in the past 10 years, but not all benefit from high core counts.

Testing the AMD Ryzen 9 7900: Integrated Graphics Benchmarks

No, this isn't a repeat of the last benchmarks; the integrated GPU results simply reinforce the last results. And though it's past broken-record status, we'll say again the integrated graphics in Ryzen 7000 CPUs are for generic home and office use and nothing more. Apart from the 3D V-Cache-enabled models, every Ryzen 7000 CPU in these tests was in essence tied with each other.

Testing the AMD Ryzen 9 7900: Power and Heat

Now, the Ryzen 9 7900 finally gets to show its secret superpowers. Compared with the Ryzen 9 7900X, the Ryzen 9 7950X, the Core i5-13600K, and especially the Core i7-13700K gulping down electricity, the 7900 politely sipped. The Core i5-13600K had a marginal lead over the 7900 in gaming, and the two traded blows in our CPU tests. But the Core i5-13600K used considerably more power to do it (71W, or nearly 40% more in Cinebench). Likewise, compared with the 7900X, the 7900 was only a step or two behind in the CPU tests and perfectly tied in gaming, but the 7900X was also using much more power (101W, or 55% more in Cinebench). It was almost embarrassing for the Core i7-13700K, having performed 10% to 20% ahead of the 7900 in our tests, but needing twice the power to do it.

It wasn't surprising to see the 7900 operate much cooler compared with the non-X Ryzen chips. It was also not too surprising that it ran just as cool as the Ryzen 7 7700, since both have the same 65W TDP and 88W socket power draw. What was surprising is that the Ryzen 9 7900 operated four more cores than the Ryzen 7 7700 using the same power limit without any massive clock drops. With AMD and Intel seemingly racing to the power-draw pole position with their recent performance chips, this level of efficiency is not only welcome but also quite impressive.

Testing the AMD Ryzen 9 7900: Wraith Prism Cooler

Having just raved about the Ryzen 9 7900's efficiency, it's important to see if it was only the result of the big liquid cooler on the test bed. As a non-X CPU, the 7900 ships with AMD's Wraith Prism cooler, the same one that ships with the Ryzen 7 7700. The Prism is rated to 105W TDP, which should be more than suitable.

As we see, the Wraith doesn't quite keep up with the Cooler Master AIO we use on the test bed, but that's almost splitting hairs. The 3 degree C delta is insignificant, as the CPU maintains the same clock speed. The Cinebench runs under both coolers were within 1.5% of each other, well within the margin of error of the test. As the Ryzen 9 7900 under the Wraith was still 20 degrees C under its thermal maximum, overclocking is still wide open, whether you want to simply use an auto-overclocking utility or AMD Ryzen Master to set a custom power limit. A 7900 under a Wraith may even be able to catch a 7900X given how close they already are in performance.
"]
ground_truth: The AMD Ryzen 9 7900 offers significant benefits in terms of power efficiency and performance per watt. Compared to its counterparts, it consumes less power while maintaining competitive performance levels. Specifically, it sips power politely compared to the Ryzen 9 7900X and the Core i7-13700K, which consume considerably more power for similar or slightly better performance. The 7900 operates much cooler and more efficiently, even with more cores than the Ryzen 7 7700, without significant clock drops, showcasing impressive efficiency with the same power limit. This level of efficiency is notable, especially in a market where AMD and Intel are competing for performance chips that consume a lot of power.

question: How do the GeForce RTX 40 series and Radeon RX 7000 series graphics cards compare in terms of price, features, and performance?
answer:
Based on the information gathered, here is a comparison between the GeForce RTX 40 series and Radeon RX 7000 series graphics cards in terms of price, features, and performance:

**Price:**
- Nvidia's RTX 40 series includes cards like the GeForce RTX 4080 priced at $1,199 and the RTX 4090 priced at $1,599.
- AMD's Radeon RX 7000 series features cards like the RX 7900 XT priced at $899 and the 7900 XTX priced at $999.

**Features:**
- Both series offer ray tracing capabilities, but Nvidia's RTX 40 series is known for advanced features like DLSS 3.0, AI-based noise removal, and virtual backgrounds for content creators.
- AMD's RX 7000 series also supports ray tracing and features an AI-based rendering technology called FSR, but it may not be as developed as Nvidia's DLSS.

**Performance:**
- In terms of performance, AMD cards like the RX 7900 XT have been ranked ahead of Nvidia's RTX 4080 in overall performance by some sources, despite being priced lower.
- Nvidia cards tend to have an advantage in newer games with more advanced graphical features and may perform better when enabling features like ray tracing.

**Overall:**
- Nvidia cards are typically viewed as more powerful with advanced features, while AMD cards are often more affordable and energy-efficient.
- Choosing between an AMD or Nvidia graphics card ultimately depends on personal needs, budget, and preferences, with Nvidia cards excelling in high-performance gaming and advanced features, while AMD cards offer competitive performance at a lower price point.

In conclusion, both the GeForce RTX 40 series and Radeon RX 7000 series graphics cards have their strengths and cater to different needs in the market. The decision on which to choose would depend on individual requirements and budget considerations.

PLEASE REVIEW
contexts:
[" earn an affiliate commission. Learn more

In the world of PC gaming, AMD and Nvidia dominate the graphics card market. Whether it's a custom computer or a pre-built model, a graphics card is essential for rendering games in high quality, and cards from either Nvidia or AMD are what you'll find in all of the best gaming PCs and best gaming laptops.

Both brands offer a range of graphics cards with entry-level models starting at around $270 and high-end cards costing $1,500 or more. AMD and Nvidia also allow other manufacturers to sell third-party versions of their cards based on their original specs. This can create price variations among models with similar capabilities, since third-party manufacturers may add features like extra fans or lighting.

While there are lots of graphics cards to choose from, it's still possible to compare each brand's overall performance in relation to their price. Premium Nvidia graphics cards are typically viewed as the most powerful when it comes to advanced features, while the best AMD cards have a reputation for being significantly more affordable and energy efficient.

Below, we've broken down details on all the latest graphics cards from Nvidia and AMD, and compare how they stack up.

Advertisement

AMD vs. Nvidia: Price and features

AMD and Nvidia both offer a range of graphics cards for different budgets and performance needs. Nvidia's current lineup is called the GeForce RTX 40 series, while AMD's lineup is called the Radeon RX 7000 series. Here's a rundown of each series.

Note: The cards listed below are for desktop computers. Both brands also make mobile versions of their cards that PC manufacturers can integrate into their gaming laptops, but performance may vary.

Advertisement

Nvidia GeForce RTX 40 series graphics cards

The Nvidia GeForce RTX 4090 is the company's most powerful graphics card. Nvidia

Nvidia's RTX 40 series debuted in fall 2022 with the release of the flagship GeForce RTX 4080 ($1,199) and the premium RTX 4090 ($1,599); four more affordable RTX 40 series cards arrived in 2023.

RTX 40 series cards share a wide range of features, including raytracing, an advanced lighting feature that requires a compatible graphics card, and DLSS 3.0, the latest version of Nvidia's AI-enhanced upscaling technology that makes games easier to run at high frame rates.

Other Nvidia features are designed to benefit content creators; RTX cards include support for AI-based noise removal for your microphone and virtual backgrounds for your webcam, as well as face tracking and auto-focus. However, AMD reports that its graphics cards actually render video faster than the RTX 40 series with common editing programs like Adobe Premiere Pro and DaVinci Resolve Studio.

Advertisement

AMD Radeon RX 7000 series graphics cards

An AMD Radeon RX 7000 series card being used with an AMD Ryzen CPU. XFX

AMD launched the Radeon RX 7000 series of graphics cards in December 2022 with the RX 7900 XT ($899) and 7900 XTX ($999), followed by the release of several lower priced cards in 2023, including the 7700XT and 7800XT which are set to launch on September 6.

AMD cards offer similar performance to Nvidia cards in most games, and usually for a lower price. For example, Tom's Hardware ranks the RX 7900 XT ($999) ahead of the RTX 4080 ($1,199) in terms of overall performance, despite the AMD card typically being $200 cheaper. However, Nvidia cards tend to reveal bigger advantages when you play newer games with more advanced graphical features.

Like the RTX 40 series, AMD's RX 7000 cards do feature ray tracing, but ray tracing performance generally lags behind the RTX 40 series with slower frame rates. The RX 7000 series also has an AI-based rendering feature to improve frame rates, called FSR, but it's not quite as developed as Nvidia's DLSS.

If you're looking to play newer releases like Cyberpunk 2077 or Allen Wake 2, a weaker AMD card may struggle to deliver graphics at the highest possible quality. That said, AMD does partner with some developers to boost performance on AMD hardware; for example, Microsoft's Starfield was designed with support for AMD's FSR at release, but not DLSS.

AMD also supports a feature called Smart Access Memory to improve performance when you pair its latest CPUs and GPUs together. This feature allows the CPU to use more of the graphics card's memory. However, some Nvidia and Intel hardware can take advantage of a similar feature, called Resizable Bar, so the underlying tech isn't AMD exclusive.

AMD benchmark data that shows RX 7000 graphics cards outperforming Nvidia hardware exclusively use AMD processors during testing, so if you have an Intel processor, you may want to look at publicly sourced benchmarks before buying an AMD card.

The target resolution and refresh rates for each graphics card were determined based on benchmarks shared by Nvidia, AMD, and crowd sourced"]
ground_truth: The GeForce RTX 40 series and Radeon RX 7000 series graphics cards offer different price points, features, and performance levels. Nvidia's RTX 40 series, including the flagship RTX 4090, is known for its advanced features like ray tracing and DLSS 3.0, which enhance gaming and content creation. These cards are typically more expensive, with the RTX 4090 priced at $1,599. AMD's Radeon RX 7000 series, including the RX 7900 XT and 7900 XTX, is generally more affordable, with the RX 7900 XT priced at $899 and the 7900 XTX at $999. AMD cards are competitive in performance, often offering similar gaming experiences for a lower price. However, Nvidia cards may have an edge in newer games with advanced graphical features. Both series support ray tracing, but Nvidia's performance in this area is generally better. AMD's RX 7000 series includes an AI-based rendering feature called FSR, though it's not as developed as Nvidia's DLSS. AMD also offers Smart Access Memory for improved performance when paired with AMD CPUs, a feature somewhat mirrored by Nvidia and Intel's Resizable Bar technology.

question: How does the MI300X's performance in generative AI tasks compare to the MI250 with ROCm 6?
answer:
The MI300X, AMD's most-advanced GPU for artificial intelligence, is positioned to challenge Nvidia's dominance in the AI chip market. Here is a comparison of the performance of the MI300X in generative AI tasks compared to the MI250 with ROCm 6 based on the gathered information:

- The MI300X is designed to be a powerful AI accelerator, aiming to compete with Nvidia's GPUs, which are widely used in cutting-edge AI programs like ChatGPT.
- AMD's CEO Lisa Su highlighted that AI is a significant growth opportunity for the company, with the data center AI accelerator market expected to grow substantially in the coming years.
- The MI300X boasts impressive specifications, including up to 192GB of high-bandwidth HBM3 memory, 13 chiplets on the die, and a memory bandwidth of 5.2 TB/s, making it a robust option for AI tasks.
- AMD claims that the MI300X can perform the work of multiple GPUs, potentially reducing the number of GPUs needed for large language models, which is crucial for generative AI applications.
- The MI300X is said to be eight times more powerful and five times more energy-efficient than the previous MI250X model, showcasing significant advancements in performance and efficiency.
- AMD plans to start shipping the MI300X to customers later this year, with expectations for broader availability in the following year.

In contrast, the information gathered does not provide specific details about the MI250 with ROCm 6 to directly compare its performance in generative AI tasks with the MI300X. However, based on the details provided about the MI300X's capabilities and advancements, it is evident that the MI300X is a substantial leap forward in AI processing power and efficiency compared to its predecessor, the MI250X.

In summary, the MI300X from AMD appears to offer a significant improvement in performance and efficiency for generative AI tasks compared to previous models, positioning it as a strong contender against Nvidia's GPUs in the AI chip market.

question: What sets apart the audience for AMD's "X" CPUs, given their heat and power use, from those choosing less power-intensive options, considering cooling and performance?
answer:
The audience for AMD's "X" CPUs, especially the Ryzen 7000 series, is diverse and can be segmented based on various factors related to heat, power use, cooling, and performance. Here are some key points that set apart the audience for AMD's "X" CPUs from those choosing less power-intensive options:

1. **Efficiency-Minded High-End Users**:
   - The non-"X" variants of AMD's Ryzen 7000 processors are ideal for efficiency-minded high-end users who prioritize power consumption and cooling efficiency.
   - These users may prefer CPUs like the Ryzen 9 7900, which offers exceptional performance per watt and includes an effective stock cooler in the box.

2. **Budget Buyers**:
   - Budget buyers may opt for CPUs without the "X" designation, as they are typically more power-efficient and come with a serviceable cooler, making them a cost-effective choice.
   - The Ryzen 7000 processors without the "X" are tweaked in terms of clock and power settings to bring them under 100 watts, catering to users who want to balance performance and cost.

3. **Performance Enthusiasts**:
   - Performance enthusiasts who prioritize raw speed and record-breaking performance may lean towards CPUs with the "X" designation, such as the Ryzen 9 7900X.
   - These CPUs are designed for maximum performance at the cost of higher power draw and heat output, appealing to users who demand top-tier performance and are willing to invest in aftermarket cooling solutions.

4. **Heavy Number-Crunching Users**:
   - Users who require heavy number-crunching capabilities or run servers that operate for extended periods may benefit from CPUs like the Ryzen 9 7900, which offer efficient power consumption and lower heat output.
   - The Ryzen 9 7900's efficiency can help reduce electricity costs and minimize the environmental impact associated with high-power CPUs.

In summary, the audience for AMD's "X" CPUs, with their focus on performance and power draw, differs from those opting for less power-intensive options, which prioritize efficiency and cost-effectiveness in cooling and power consumption.

**PLEASE REVIEW**
contexts:
[' processors we’ve reviewed to date have hit their thermal limit while under heavy load, even with a 240mm water cooler, and after doing so they throttle back to prevent their temperatures from rising any further.

(Credit: Michael Justin Allen Sexton)

This is something of a "maximum performance at all costs" approach, as the processor attempts to achieve as much performance as possible within its thermal limitations. This has come along with a greatly increased power draw, and it's the reason AMD's CPUs ending in "X" don't include coolers in the box. Chips pulling as much as 230W from the CPU socket are far too hot for an inexpensive stock cooler to handle. However, as these CPUs are meant primarily for the high-performance enthusiast crowd that mostly uses aftermarket coolers anyway, it's not a huge concern.

(Credit: Michael Justin Allen Sexton)

If you don't want your desktop to double as a space heater, AMD released lower-power models of existing processors, denoted by the lack of an X at the end of the product name. These non-X variants are put on a strict electrical diet. The 7900X has a 170W thermal design power, or TDP, and a 230W maximum socket draw. The Ryzen 9 7900 consumes a third of that, using the same 65W TDP and 88W socket draw as the AMD Ryzen 7 7700. However, this might be more restrictive for the 7900, as it has four more cores to feed than the 7700. To adjust for this lower power consumption, the base clock rate is down to 3.7GHz, compared with the 7900X at 4.7GHz. The maximum boost frequency is also reduced, from 5.6GHz to 5.4GHz.

(Credit: Michael Justin Allen Sexton)

As with the previous Ryzen generation, the Ryzen 7000X and non-X CPUs are identical from a hardware standpoint. Both the 7900 and 7900X use a two-CCD chiplet design with an Infinity Fabric interconnect between them. Each CCD has eight cores, and two cores on each CCD are disabled. This results in a 12-core/24-thread CPU. Each core has 64K of L1 cache and 1MB of L2 cache attached, and 64MB of L3 cache is shared among all 12 cores.

(Credit: Michael Justin Allen Sexton)

The included cooler is AMD's Wraith Prism model. For a stock cooler, it's a rather capable unit. A copper contact slug and heat pipes provide better heat transfer than all aluminum designs. The fin stack is fairly large and dense, making the cooler rated for 105W TDP processors. For a touch of style, it also has programmable RGB lighting. As it's a downdraft cooler, instead of the more common tower coolers, it should also provide much better airflow and cooling over the RAM and VRMs of whatever motherboard on which it's used.

(Credit: Michael Justin Allen Sexton)

AMD Ryzen 9 7900: Our Test Setup

AMD's Ryzen 9 7900 was benchmarked on our updated AMD AM5 test station. In short, the test bed is an ASRock X670E Taichi motherboard with 32GB of DDR5 memory clocked at the CPU's maximum supported RAM frequency (DDR5-5200). CPU cooling is handled by a Cooler Master PL240 Flux all-in-one liquid cooler, while an Nvidia GeForce RTX 3080 Founders Edition provides discrete graphics power. All of it is mounted on a Praxis Wetbench open-frame PC case with a SilverStone DA850 power supply handling power duties.

Benchmarks specifically testing integrated graphics were run on the Ryzen 9 7900's integrated graphics or IGP. All other tests used the GeForce RTX 3080.

Testing the AMD Ryzen 9 7900: CPU Benchmarks

Checking system memory bandwidth, we see the Ryzen 9 7900 tied with the 7900X, as we would expect. With the 7900X having nearly thrice the TDP, we expected it to be able to sustain much higher clocks than the 7900. But the AIDA cache results showed the 7900 much closer than anticipated.

L1 and L2 cache rates were only 5% or less behind the 7900X chip. Things changed in the L3 bandwidth, as the Ryzen 9 7900's read rate fell to 10% behind the 7900X, while the L3 write was almost 30% slower, only a little faster than the Ryzen 7 7700 models.

The Ryzen 9 7900 unexpectedly tied with the 7900X in the Adobe Premiere benchmark. This is an important reminder that not all execution threads are similarly demanding. For example, AVX instructions tend to be markedly power-hungry and generate a lot of heat. It would appear the Ryzen 9 7900X, with its higher']
ground_truth: The audience for AMD's "X" CPUs is primarily the high-performance enthusiast crowd, as these CPUs have a greatly increased power draw and hit their thermal limit under heavy load, necessitating aftermarket coolers due to their exclusion of coolers in the box. In contrast, those choosing less power-intensive options, like the non-X variants, are likely more concerned with power efficiency and avoiding the high heat output, as these models have a lower power draw and are designed to be more restrictive in terms of electrical consumption, making them suitable for users who do not want their desktop to double as a space heater.

question: What advantages does HBM3 memory technology provide in the context of AMD's MI300X accelerator?
answer:
The HBM3 memory technology in AMD's MI300X accelerator provides several advantages in the context of this accelerator:

1. **High Memory Bandwidth**: The MI300X accelerator comes with up to 192GB of high-bandwidth HBM3 memory shared by both the CPU and GPU. This high memory bandwidth of 5.2 TB/s is 60% faster than Nvidia's H100, enhancing overall performance.

2. **Reduced GPU Dependency**: With the increased memory capacity provided by HBM3 technology, the MI300X allows for the reduction of the number of GPUs needed to run large language models. This reduction in GPU dependency can lead to more efficient operations.

3. **Energy Efficiency**: The MI300X is designed to be five times more energy efficient than its predecessor, the MI250X. This energy efficiency can result in cost savings and a more sustainable operation.

4. **Improved Performance**: AMD claims that the MI300X is eight times more powerful than the MI250X used in the Frontier supercomputer. This enhanced performance can lead to faster processing and improved overall efficiency.

5. **Compatibility and Integration**: The MI300X accelerator is designed to work with large language models, making it suitable for tasks requiring significant memory and compute resources. Additionally, AMD has partnered with Microsoft to deploy MI300X in Azure virtual machines, showcasing its compatibility and integration capabilities.

In summary, the HBM3 memory technology in AMD's MI300X accelerator offers high memory bandwidth, reduced GPU dependency, energy efficiency, improved performance, and compatibility with large language models, making it a powerful and efficient solution for AI processing tasks.

question: What AMD innovations boost AI training and network openness in HPC?
answer:
AMD has made significant strides in boosting AI training and network openness in HPC (High-Performance Computing) through various innovations and acquisitions. Here are the key points related to AMD's innovations in this area:

- In October 2023, AMD acquired Nod, Inc., an open AI software company, to enhance its AI software capabilities. Nod, Inc.'s technology is designed to accelerate the deployment of AI solutions optimized for various AMD products, including Instinct data center accelerators, Ryzen AI processors, EPYC processors, Versal SoCs, and Radeon GPUs.
- AMD's net revenue for 2023 was $22.7 billion, with a focus on AI-driven solutions and data center products like AMD Instinct GPUs and 4th Gen AMD EPYC CPUs.
- The company's gross margin for 2023 was 46%, reflecting an increase from the previous year, driven by higher revenue in the Embedded segment and lower amortization of acquisition-related intangible assets.
- Despite a decrease in operating income and net income for 2023 compared to the prior year, AMD continues to invest in R&D to drive innovation in AI and high-performance computing.
- AMD's strategic focus on AI-driven solutions, data center products, and software development aligns with the growing demand for generative AI models and AI applications in various industries.

In summary, AMD's acquisitions, product offerings, and focus on AI-driven solutions demonstrate its commitment to advancing AI training and network openness in the field of high-performance computing.

question: How does the ARPU by geography affect Facebook's revenue and financial results?
answer:
The Average Revenue Per User (ARPU) by geography significantly impacts Facebook's revenue and financial results. Here are the key points related to this impact:

- Facebook calculates its revenue by user geography based on where ad impressions are delivered, virtual and digital goods are purchased, or consumer hardware products are shipped.
- ARPU is defined as the total revenue in a specific geography during a quarter divided by the average number of Monthly Active Users (MAUs) in that geography at the beginning and end of the quarter.
- Revenue and ARPU vary across different regions due to the varying rates of monetization. Regions like the United States & Canada and Europe have higher ARPU compared to regions like Asia-Pacific.
- The revenue from users who are Facebook or Messenger MAUs represents a substantial majority of Facebook's total revenue.
- The annual worldwide ARPU in 2023 was $44.60, with increases in ARPU seen in Europe, Rest of World, Asia-Pacific, and United States & Canada.
- User growth is concentrated in regions with relatively lower ARPU, such as Asia-Pacific and Rest of World, which may impact the overall ARPU trends.
- Facebook's financial statements are prepared in accordance with GAAP and involve critical accounting estimates related to loss contingencies, income taxes, and valuation of assets.

In summary, the ARPU by geography plays a crucial role in determining Facebook's revenue and financial performance, with different regions contributing varying levels of revenue based on user monetization rates.

PLEASE REVIEW

We define a monthly active user as a registered and logged-in Facebook user who visited Facebook through our website or a mobile device, or used our Messenger application (and is also a registered Facebook user), in the last 30 days as of the date of measurement. MAUs are a measure of the size of our global active user community on Facebook. As of December 31, 2023, we had 3.07 billion MAUs, an increase of 3% from December 31, 2022. Users in India, Bangladesh, and Nigeria represented the top three sources of growth in 2023, relative to the same period in 2022. Table of Contents Trends in Our Monetization by Facebook User Geography We calculate our revenue by user geography based on our estimate of the geography in which ad impressions are delivered, virtual and digital goods are purchased, or consumer hardware products are shipped. We define ARPU as our total revenue in a given geography during a given quarter, divided by the average of the number of MAUs in the geography at the beginning and end of the quarter. While ARPU includes all sources of revenue, the number of MAUs used in this calculation only includes users of Facebook and Messenger as described in the definition of MAU above.

While the share of revenue from users who are not also Facebook or Messenger MAUs has grown over time, we estimate that revenue from users who are Facebook or Messenger MAUs represents the substantial majority of our total revenue. See "Average Revenue Per Person (ARPP)" above for our estimates of trends in our monetization of our Family products. The geography of our users affects our revenue and financial results because we currently monetize users in different geographies at different average rates. Our revenue and ARPU in regions such as United States & Canada and Europe are relatively higher primarily due to the size and maturity of those online and mobile advertising markets. For example, ARPU in 2023 in the United States & Canada region was more than 11 times higher than in the Asia-Pacific region.

question: How does the MI300X's genAI speed or efficiency compare to the MI250 with ROCm 5?
answer:
The AMD Instinct MI300X is designed to be more powerful and energy-efficient compared to the MI250X with ROCm 5. Here are some key points to consider:

- The MI300X is claimed to be eight times more powerful than the existing MI250X used in Frontier, the world's fastest supercomputer.
- AMD's MI300X comes with up to 192GB of high-bandwidth HBM3 memory shared by both the CPU and GPU, which is a significant improvement.
- The MI300X has a memory bandwidth of 5.2 TB/s, which is 60% faster than Nvidia's H100.
- AMD states that the design of the MI300X allows for fewer GPUs to be needed for running large language models, making it more efficient in handling complex AI workloads.
- The MI300X is said to be five times more energy-efficient than the MI250X, showcasing a significant improvement in energy consumption.

Overall, the MI300X offers a substantial boost in performance and efficiency compared to the MI250X with ROCm 5, making it a promising advancement in the field of AI acceleration.

question: How should investors view NVIDIA's AI-driven gains vs. TSMC's valuation amid geopolitical concerns?
answer:
Investors should consider the following points when comparing Nvidia's AI-driven gains to TSMC's valuation amid geopolitical concerns:

**Nvidia (NVDA):**
- Nvidia has experienced a significant rally due to its AI-driven growth, with analysts projecting further upside potential.
- Analysts like Hans Mosesmann of Rosenblatt Securities anticipate Nvidia stock more than doubling over the next 12 months, potentially exceeding $1,000.
- Concerns over Nvidia's valuation have eased as the company consistently beats earnings expectations and provides a positive outlook.
- Despite challenges such as export restrictions to China and emerging competition, analysts remain bullish on Nvidia's future growth prospects.
- The average 12-month price target for Nvidia implies a further upside potential of 37.22% from current levels.

**TSMC (TSM):**
- TSMC has been a popular stock recently, with a positive return over the past month.
- While TSMC faces challenges like declining revenue growth and geopolitical concerns, analysts maintain a Hold rating on the stock.
- TSMC's valuation is considered to be in line with its peers, indicating fair pricing relative to the industry.
- The company has a track record of beating earnings estimates, but revenue growth has been declining.
- TSMC's future performance is expected to be in line with the broader market in the near term.

In summary, investors should weigh the following factors:
- Nvidia's strong AI-driven growth potential and positive outlook.
- TSMC's stable performance but challenges in revenue growth and geopolitical uncertainties.
- Valuation metrics for both companies compared to their peers.
- Analyst recommendations and price targets for each stock.

By considering these points, investors can make informed decisions based on the current market conditions and the outlook for both Nvidia and TSMC.

**PLEASE REVIEW**
contexts:
[' about asset bubbles, it’s that they pop — eventually.

NVIDIA skyrocketed nearly 30% just in the last five days to hit a new record high of about $419 after reporting a 21% year-over-year increase in net income for the first quarter. Management also used a key phrase in their earnings commentary that helped drive that massive rally: “generative AI.”

The hype over artificial intelligence this year — likely stemming from the release of ChatGPT — has boosted the shares of virtually every company that has anything to do with AI. In his earnings commentary, NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang predicted that $1 trillion worth of installed global data infrastructure “will transition from general-purpose to accelerated computing as companies race to apply generative AI into every product, service, and business process.”

Notably, NVIDIA’s data-center revenue surged to a record $4.28 billion in the first quarter. While the chipmaker is and will continue to be a winner in the AI race, euphoria doesn’t last forever, and the shares have flattened out after their initial earnings-related surge.

In fact, insiders have unloaded almost $8 million worth of NVIDIA shares over the last three months, and the rally over the last five days suggests more sales could be reported soon.

Is Nvidia a Buy, Sell, or Hold?

NVIDIA has a Strong Buy consensus rating based on 33 Buys, four Holds, and zero Sell ratings assigned over the last three months. At $441.84, the average NVIDIA stock price target implies an upside potential of 15.47%.

Taiwan Semiconductor (NYSE:TSM)

At a P/E of 15.5 and a P/S of 6.4, Taiwan Semiconductor trades at a discount to its industry P/E and in line with its industry P/S. Thus, it looks much more reasonably valued than NVIDIA, especially considering its five-year mean P/S of eight. However, a neutral view might be appropriate in the near term due to the geopolitical overhang for Taiwanese stocks.

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing has enjoyed a nice 11% lift over the last five days due to NVIDIA’s good news, enjoying their best week in almost a year. TSM is likely to see some sales increase from the AI transition because it manufactures NVIDIA’s chips, but any impact is likely to be modest.

Unfortunately, the company could face issues amid the growing tensions between Taiwan and China, which convinced Warren Buffett to dump most of his $4.1 billion stake after less than a year. Given Buffett’s long-term focus, it’s highly unusual that he would sell the position after holding it for such a short time.

Thus, while Taiwan Semiconductor could end up being an excellent long-term investment at current prices, the recent rally paired with the geopolitical tensions suggests a neutral view for now.

Is Taiwan Semiconductor a Buy, Sell, or Hold?

Taiwan Semiconductor has a Strong Buy consensus rating based on four Buys, zero Holds, and zero Sells assigned over the last three months. At $118.67, the average Taiwan Semiconductor stock price target implies upside potential of 19.93%.

Conclusion: Bearish on NVDA, Neutral on TSM

NVIDIA and TSM clearly have excellent long-term prospects, given their AI exposure. However, it seems like buying NVIDIA shares at current prices could be playing with fire, given its bubble-like aspects that could bring a better entry price.

TSM’s valuation is more attractive and could be a good play on AI, but the geopolitical overhang adds significant risk to owning the shares.

Disclosure Lisa Su displays an AMD Instinct MI300 chip as she delivers a keynote address at CES 2023 in Las Vegas, Nevada, on Jan. 4, 2023.

AMD said on Tuesday its most-advanced GPU for artificial intelligence, the MI300X, will start shipping to some customers later this year.

AMD's announcement represents the strongest challenge to Nvidia , which currently dominates the market for AI chips with over 80% market share, according to analysts.

GPUs are chips used by firms like OpenAI to build cutting-edge AI programs such as ChatGPT.

If AMD's AI chips, which it calls "accelerators," are embraced by developers and server makers as substitutes for Nvidia's products, it could represent a big untapped market for the chipmaker, which is best known for its traditional computer processors.

AMD CEO Lisa Su told investors and analysts in San Francisco on Tuesday that AI is the company's "largest and most strategic long-term growth opportunity."

"We think about the data center AI accelerator [market] growing from something like $30 billion this year, at over 50']
ground_truth: Investors should view NVIDIA's AI-driven gains with caution due to its bubble-like aspects that could bring a better entry price, while TSMC's valuation is more attractive and could be a good play on AI. However, the geopolitical overhang adds significant risk to owning TSMC shares, suggesting a neutral view for now.

question: How does the MI300A's unified memory boost its speed and efficiency over the H100?
answer:
The MI300X processor's unified memory boosts its speed and efficiency over the H100 in the following ways:

- The MI300X comes with up to 192GB of high-bandwidth HBM3 memory shared by both the CPU and GPU, providing a significant amount of memory that is shared between the two components.
- The chip has a memory bandwidth of 5.2 TB/s, which is 60% faster than Nvidia's H100, allowing for faster data transfer and processing.
- With the large memory capacity and bandwidth, the MI300X can reduce the number of GPUs needed to run large language models, making it more efficient in handling complex tasks.
- The design of the MI300X makes it eight times more powerful than the existing MI250X and five times more energy efficient, showcasing a significant improvement in performance and energy consumption.

In summary, the unified memory architecture of the MI300X processor with its large memory capacity, high bandwidth, and efficient design allows it to outperform the H100 in terms of speed and efficiency, making it a powerful and energy-efficient option for handling demanding workloads.

PLEASE REVIEW

question: What specific advancements in datacenter technology have been achieved through the AMD and Meta partnership, particularly since their collaboration began in 2019 focusing on CPUs and later expanded to include the use of Instinct GPUs in Meta's datacenters?
answer:
The advancements in datacenter technology achieved through the AMD and Meta partnership include:

1. **AMD Instinct MI300 Data Center GPU Accelerator Family Launch**:
   - AMD announced the launch of the next-generation AMD Instinct MI300 data center GPU accelerator family. This new product aims to reshape the AI, adaptive, and high-performance computing landscape.
   - The event, titled "Advancing AI," highlighted the growing momentum of AMD with AI hardware and software partners, showcasing how AMD products and software are influencing the industry.

2. **Samsung and AMD Collaboration**:
   - Samsung and AMD signed a multi-year agreement extension to incorporate multiple generations of high-performance AMD Radeon graphics solutions into an expanded portfolio of Samsung Exynos SoCs.
   - This collaboration aims to bring console-level graphics quality and optimized power consumption to more mobile devices, enhancing the gaming experience on mobile platforms.

3. **Meta's Custom Chip for AI Models**:
   - Meta announced the development of its first custom chip, the MTIA (Meta Training and Inference Accelerator), designed specifically for running AI models.
   - The MTIA chip targets inference workloads, providing greater compute power and efficiency compared to CPUs. It is customized for Meta's internal workloads to enhance performance, decrease latency, and improve efficiency.
   - In addition to the MTIA chip, Meta introduced the MSVP (Meta Scalable Video Processor), an ASIC designed to support high-quality transcoding for VOD and low latency processing for live streaming. This technology will support AI-made content and AR- and VR-specific content in Meta's applications.

These advancements showcase the collaborative efforts between AMD and Meta to drive innovation in datacenter technology, particularly focusing on CPUs, GPUs, and custom chips tailored for AI workloads.

**PLEASE REVIEW**
